STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 8, 2020
Brandon Hannah
Ennis Center for Children - Pontiac
91 S. Telegraph
Pontiac, MI 48341
RE: License #: CB630315340
Ennis Center for Children - Pontiac
91 S. Telegraph
Pontiac, MI 48341
Dear Mr. Hannah:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
May 11-20,2020. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of
this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat violations, explain why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Alicia Wiggins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 917-1048
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB630315340
Licensee Name: Ennis Center for Children Inc
Licensee Address: 20100 Greenfield Road
Detroit, MI 48235
Licensee Telephone #: (313) 342-2699

Robert Ennis, Designee
Name of Facility: Ennis Center for Children - Pontiac
Facility Address: 91 S. Telegraph
Pontiac, MI 48341
Facility Telephone #: (248) 334-2715

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have training
in and maintain a current certification in first aid from the
American Heart Association or the American Red Cross or other
institution approved by the department.
In one out of six certification records reviewed, there was no documentation that at
least one adult household member had current first aid training. The last first aid
training was completed on October 10, 2017.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2018 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
June 26, 2018.
R 400.12319 Substitute care policy.
An agency's substitute care policy shall, at a minimum, contain
provisions for all of the following:
(a) Qualifications for substitute caregivers, consistent with
the requirements of 1973 PA 116 and child care licensing rules.
In one out of six certification records reviewed, there was no documentation that a
central registry clearance and criminal history check were completed for the foster
parent’s substitute caregiver.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(a) Prior approval from the certifying agency authorizing the
placement of a child in the home.
(b) Documentation that the foster parent is willing to accept
the foster child.
(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written endorsement
by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is acceptable.
(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is
acceptable.
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement signed by
the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
4

(2) The borrowing agency is responsible for securing the items
identified in subrules (1) (d), (e), (g), (h), and (i) of this rule
annually for the duration of the child's placement.
(1)(a) In one out of three borrowed home records reviewed, the agency did not
receive prior approval from the certifying agency authorizing the placement of the
child in the home before the child was placed in the home. The borrowed bed
effective date was December 12, 2019 and the certifying agency signed the
borrowed bed agreement letter on February 11, 2020.
(1)(b) In one out of three borrowed home records reviewed, the documentation did
not show that the foster parent was willing to accept the foster child before the child
was placed in the home. The borrowed bed effective date was December 12, 2019
and the foster parents signed the borrowed bed agreement letter on February 4,
2020.
(1)(c) In one out of three borrowed home records reviewed, the agency’s written
endorsement that the initial evaluation is acceptable occurred after the child was
placed in the home. The borrowed bed effective date was December 12, 2019 and
the agency’s written endorsement was on February 11, 2020.
(1)(d) In one out of three borrowed home records reviewed, the agency’s written
endorsement that the current reevaluation was acceptable occurred after the child
was placed in the home. The borrowed bed effective date was December 12, 2019
and the agency’s written endorsement was on February 11, 2020.
(1)(f) In one out of three borrowed home records reviewed, the foster parent did not
receive orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency before the child was
placed in the home. The borrowed bed effective date was December 12, 2019 and
the foster parents signed the agency’s policies and procedures form on February 4,
2020.
(1)(g) In one out of three borrowed home records reviewed, the foster parent did not
sign a copy of the foster parent /agency agreement before the child was placed in
the home. The borrowed bed effective date was December 12, 2019 and the foster
parents signed the foster parent/agency agreement on February 4, 2020.
(2) One out three borrowed home records reviewed required items to be collected
annually. In one out of one borrowed home records reviewed the 2019 signed foster
home license application was not in the record.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED for (1)(c) —2018 Renewal Inspection, CAP
approved June 26, 2018.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
5

(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within 45
calendar days after receipt of the information. If additional time
is required, then the agency shall inform the foster parent, in
writing, of the basis for the extension and the expected length of
the extension. The total time for the completion of the
investigation shall not exceed 90 calendar days without written
approval from the chief administrator or his or her designee.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children are
interviewed, their last names shall not be included in the report.
(3) In one out of three special evaluations reviewed, the special evaluation was not
completed within 45 calendar days after the receipt of the information. The agency
completed a 45 day extension letter, which indicated that the extension was needed
to write the report not to complete the investigation. The intake date was August 6,
2019 and the report was completed on September 24, 2019.
(5)(d) In two out of three special evaluations reviewed, the children’s last names
were included in the report.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED for (5)(d) —2018 Renewal Inspection, CAP
approved June 26, 2018.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child placing
agency to another child placing agency, a modified service plan
must be completed within 30 calendar days of the change in
agency responsibility if no other plan is done within 30 days.
The plan shall address why the agency responsibility changed
and whether there are any modifications to existing service
plans.
6

(2)(b) In two out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, an updated service plan
(USP) was not completed at least once every 90 calendar days.
 For one foster child’s record, the USP was due on August 24, 2019 and it was
completed on August 27, 2019.
 For one foster child’s record, the USP was due on April 17, 2020 and it was
completed on April 22, 2020.
(3) In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, in which a modified service
plan was required, the modified service plan was not completed within 30 days of
the agency receiving case responsibility. The agency received case responsibility
on September 6, 2019 and the modified service plan was not completed.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2018 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
June 26, 2018.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
September 4, 2019.
Public Act 116 Confidentiality.
722.120
A licensee shall keep the records the department prescribes
regarding each child in its control and care and shall report to
the department, when requested, the facts the department
requires with reference to the children upon forms furnished by
the department. Except as otherwise provided in this subsection
and subsection (4), records regarding children and facts
compiled about children and their parents and relatives are
confidential and disclosure of this information shall be properly
safeguarded by the child care organization, the department, and
any other entity in possession of the information. Records that
are confidential under this section are available to both of the
following:
(a) A standing or select committee or appropriations
subcommittee of either house of the legislature having
jurisdiction over protective services matters for children,
according to section 7 of the child protection law, 1975 PA 238,
MCL 722.627.
(b) The children’s ombudsman established in section 3 of the
children’s ombudsman act, 1994
PA 204, MCL 722.923.
In one out of three special evaluations reviewed, the narrative included information
referencing CPS involvement.
7

2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements except for the
following:
MISEP 6.7 Maximum Children in a Foster Home.
(a) No child shall be placed in a foster home if that placement
will result in:
(1) more than three foster children in that foster home,
(2) a total of six children, including the foster family’s birth
and/or adopted children, or
(3) more than three children under the age of three residing in
that foster home.
(b) Exceptions to these limitations may be made by the Director
of the DCWL, on an individual basis, documented in the case
file, when in the best interest of the child(ren) being placed.
In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the required placement
exception request (PER) was not completed. The foster child is currently placed in a
foster home, where there is a total of seven children in the home. The foster child
has been placed in the home since March 25, 2019 and the agency received case
responsibility on October 21, 2019. The PER was completed on May 8, 2020 and is
pending approval.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED cited under ISEP 6.12 —2018 Renewal
Inspection, CAP approved June 26, 2018.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy Placement Exception Requests and Approvals: Intervention
FOM 722-03E in a Residential Facility.
Placement of a child or dual ward into a CCI must be approved
every 90 days prior to the following PER type time frames:
 Initial placement in a residential facility
 Three months from the date of initial placement
 Six months from the date of initial placement
 Nine months from the date of initial placement
8

One out of the eight foster children’s records reviewed had been placed in a child
caring institution. In one out of one foster children’s record reviewed, the PER was
not completed timely. The foster child was placed in one child caring institution on
August 1, 2019. The PER was routed to DHHS for approval on May 13, 2020 and is
pending approval. The foster child was then placed in another child caring institution
on August 20, 2019. The PER was routed to DHHS for approval on May 13, 2020
and is pending approval.
DHHS Policy Family Team Meetings: Types and Timeframes.
FOM 722-06B
The following events shall trigger FTM for out of home cases:
 Case Plan Development/ Reassessment:
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date.
Note: This FTM may be combined with the CPS Case Opening
(ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
 Placement preservation/disruption - At least three
business days prior to a planned change of placement or
no later than three business days after an unplanned
placement change. Planned and unplanned placement
changes include reunification, placement in a residential
setting, step-down from a residential or hospital setting,
return from AWOLP, or request for change in foster
home/relative placements.
 Semi-Annual Transition Meeting - within 30 calendar
days after the youth’s 14th birthday and every six months
thereafter. For youth entering out-of-home placement at
age 14 or older, the semi-annual transition meeting must
be held within 30 calendar days of the removal date; see
this item for specific meeting requirements.
Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
9

In five out eight foster children’s records reviewed, a FTM was not completed timely
or the DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting report, was not completed.
 For one foster child’s record, the activity report was not completed for the
FTM that was held on July 1, 2019.
 For one foster child’s record, a FTM for case service plan development for the
USP ending on November 22, 2019 was not completed within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date. Also, the foster child turned fourteen
years old on October 6, 2018. There has been no semi-annual transition
FTMs.
 For one foster child’s record, a FTM for case service plan development for the
USP ending on January 18, 2020 was not completed within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
 For one foster child’s record, a FTM for case service plan development for the
USP ending on November 19, 2019 was not completed within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
 For one foster child’s record, the foster child turned fourteen years old on July
30, 2019. The first semi-annual transition FTM was completed on May 6,
2020 and the DHH 901 Semi Annual Transition form was not completed.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2018 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
June 26, 2018.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
September 4, 2019.
DHHS Policy Caseworker Contact with Parent(s)/Guardian(s).
FOM 722-06H
For each child with a permanency goal of reunification, the
child’s assigned caseworker must have face-to face contact with
the child’s parent/guardian as follows:
First Month after Initial Out-of-Home Placement
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts
with each parent/guardian, at least one of which must occur in
the parent’s residence. One of the face-to-face contacts must be
used to discuss the following:
 Petition and court orders.
 Case service plan.
 Family Assessment of Needs and Strengths.
 Child Assessment of Needs and Strengths.
 Parent-Agency Treatment Plan & Service Agreement.
 Scheduling and expectations of parenting time.
Subsequent Months
The caseworker must have face-to-face contact with each
parent/guardian at least once each calendar month, with at least
one contact in each quarter occurring in the parent’s place of
residence.
10

In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, in which there was parent
involvement, there were no face-to-face contacts with the parent per the policy.
There was no face-to-face contact with the foster child’s mother in the parental home
for report period October 21, 2019-January 18, 2020. There was no contact with the
foster child’s mother in March 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
September 4, 2019.
DHHS Policy Timely Entry of Case Contacts.
FOM 722-06H
All case contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, including
attempted contacts and missed appointments. The case contact
narrative should consist of a brief summary of the contact.
The required face-to-face contacts listed below must be entered
in MISACWIS within five business days of the contact. This
includes attempted and missed face-to-face contacts.
 Any face-to-face contact with children, parents, or
caregivers made by any of the following:
Foster care caseworker/supervisor.
CPS caseworker/supervisor.
Adoption caseworker/supervisor.
Permanency resource monitors.
Education planners.
Michigan Youth Opportunities Initiative coordinators.
 Parent/child face-to-face contacts.
 Sibling face-to-face contacts.
All other case contacts must be entered prior to the report
period end date on the applicable case service plan.
In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, all of the required face-to-face
contacts were not entered in MiSACWIS within five business days of the contact.
The face-to-face contact with the foster child’s father that occurred on March 9, 2020
was entered in MiSACWIS on May 15, 2020.
DHHS Policy Maintaining Connections through Visitation and Contact:
FOM 722-06I Sibling Visitation and Ongoing Interaction.
Siblings in foster care, who are not placed together, must have
at least one visit per calendar month that is in addition to
parenting time. For the purposes of visitation only, siblings
include children related through birth, adoption, or marriage and
include siblings as defined by the American Indian or Alaskan
Native child’s tribal code or custom. A sibling relationship
continues after termination of parental rights or when a marriage
ends by death or divorce.
11

In two out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, in which siblings were not
placed together, all of the monthly sibling visits were not completed.
 For one foster child’s record, there was no sibling visit or contact in November
2019, January 2020 and March 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, there was no sibling visit in December 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2018 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
June 26, 2018.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
September 4, 2019.
DHHS Policy Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary: Placement
FOM 722-08E Change.
Prior to a planned placement change, or within three business
days of an emergency placement change, the caseworker must
document on the DHHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary, specific administrative actions or changes in a case.
In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the DHHS-69 Foster
Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary was not completed within three business
days of an emergency placement change. The foster child returned from being
AWOL and was placed at a child caring institution on August 1, 2019. The DHHS-69
Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, form was completed on October 17,
2019. The foster child was placed at another child caring institution on August 20,
2019 and the DHHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary, form was
completed on October 17, 2019.
DHHS Policy Updated Service Plan: Supervisory Approval.
FOM 722-09
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
 Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of
the report date.
12

In five out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, all of the USPs were not
reviewed and approved within 14 calendar days of the report date.
 For one foster child’s record, one USP was completed on September 3, 2019
and it was approved on October 8, 2019.
 For one foster child’s record, one USP was completed on April 8, 2020 and it
was approved on April 29, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, one USP was completed on August 27, 2019
and it was approved on September 25, 2019. A second USP was completed
on November 22, 2019 and it was approved on January 22, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, one USP was completed on January 18, 2020
and it was approved on February 18, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, one USP was completed on November 19, 2019
and it was approved on December 16, 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2018 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
June 26, 2018.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
September 4, 2019.
DHHS Policy Medical Passports.
FOM 801
For children first entering foster care, the initial medical passport
must be provided to the foster care provider within two weeks of
the child's placement date. The actual date the foster care
provider receive the medical passport must be documented in
MiSACWIS.
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
Each foster care caseworker who transfers a child's medical
passport to another caseworker must sign and date the medical
passport verifying that s/he has sought and obtained the
necessary information under law and MDHHS policy.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Legal parents, if the child is a temporary court ward.
--Quarterly.
--At reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider:
--At or prior to each placement.
--Quarterly.
13

In three out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the medical passport was not
provided to the child’s foster care provider/parent per the timeframes specified in the
policy and/or the medical passport was not completed quarterly.
 For one foster child’s record, the medical passport was not updated quarterly.
The foster child entered care on December 11, 2018 and the agency received
case responsibility on July 24, 2019. The medical passport was signed by the
relative caregiver on April 18, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, the medical passport was not updated quarterly.
The foster child entered care on November 17, 2016 and the agency received
case responsibility on January 2, 2017. The last quarterly medical passport
was signed by the foster care worker on August 13, 2019 and the foster
child’s birth parent on August 14, 2019.
 For one foster child’s record, the medical passport was not updated quarterly.
The foster child entered care on January 24, 2019 and the agency received
case responsibility on September 6, 2019. A quarterly medical passport was
signed by the foster care worker on November 19, 2019 and the foster child’s
birth mother, with no date next to the signature.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2018 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
June 26, 2018.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
September 4, 2019.
DHHS Policy Health Documentation: Dental Examination Schedule.
FOM 801
Dental examinations are required for children 3 years of age
and older, as follows:
 A dental examination within six months before entry into
foster care or an initial dental examination shall be
completed not more than 90 calendar days after entry
into a foster care out-of-home placement.
 A dental re-examination shall be obtained at least every
12 months unless a greater frequency is indicated.
 Children entering foster care under 3 years of age must
have an initial dental exam within three months of his/her
third birthday.
14

In two out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the yearly dental examinations
were not completed.
 For one foster child’s record, the yearly dental examination was due by
February 27, 2020 and it was not completed.
 For one foster child’s record, the last yearly dental examination that was
completed was on November 12, 2018.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2018 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
June 26, 2018.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2019 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
September 4, 2019.
DHHS Policy Quarterly Adoption Progress Reports.
ADM 330
Adoption workers must submit written quarterly progress reports
using the DHS-614, Quarterly Adoption Progress Report. The
adoption worker must have at least one face-to-face contact
with the child during each quarter prior to the adoption
supervision period for the purpose of completing the DHS-614.
The child adoption assessment may serve as the initial quarterly
report if it is completed within the required quarterly reporting
period and attached to the DHS-614 form.
Note: When the child adoption assessment is used as the initial
quarterly report, the next quarterly report is due 90 calendar
days from completion of the child adoption assessment. When
the child adoption assessment is not completed within the initial
required quarterly reporting period, the DHS-614 is due 90
calendar days from case acceptance or 90 days after the order
terminating parental rights is signed, whichever is later.
In one out of eight adoption records reviewed, the quarterly adoption progress report
was not completed timely. The quarterly report was due on February 13, 2020 and it
was completed on March 25, 2020.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was not offered technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
15

licensing period.
The agency received a complaint on August 6, 2019. The allegation was that on two
occasions, the foster mother slapped the foster child on the mouth with an open
hand as a form of discipline. It was reported that after the first incident, the foster
child’s lip was split, open and swollen for a couple of days. It was reported that after
the second incident there was redness on the foster child’s face for several days.
The foster home was found to be in non-compliance of R 400.9201(j) Foster parent
qualifications, R 400.9205 (3) Records check and R 400.9404 (1) and (3) Behavior
management. The agency recommended revocation of the foster home’s license.
The agency’s handling of this special evaluation was appropriate; however, the
agency received a violation for Public Act 116 722.120 Confidentiality (see
description of findings section).
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency received a complaint on August 6, 2019. The allegation was that on two
occasions, the foster mother slapped the foster child on the mouth with an open
hand as a form of discipline. It was reported that after the first incident, the foster
child’s lip was split, open and swollen for a couple of days. It was reported that after
the second incident there was redness on the foster child’s face for several days.
The foster home was found to be in non-compliance of R 400.9201(j) Foster parent
qualifications, R 400.9205 (3) Records check and R 400.9404 (1) and (3) Behavior
management. The agency recommended revocation of the foster home’s license.
The agency’s handling of this special evaluation was appropriate; however, the
agency received a violation for Public Act 116 722.120 Confidentiality (see
description of findings section).
The agency has submitted three acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted a CAP on June 26, 2018 for the Renewal Inspection that was
completed in April 2018 and May 2018. The CAP was approved on June 26, 2018.
The agency is in non-compliance with sections of the CAP, as the agency received
the following repeat violations during the current Renewal Inspection:
 R 400.12312 (4) Foster parent training
 R 400.12326 (1)(c) Borrowed home
 R 400.12327 (5)(d) Special evaluation
 R 400.12418 (2)(b) and (3) Development of service plans
 DHHS Policy FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings: Types and Timeframes
 DHHS Policy FOM 722-06I Maintaining Connections through Visitation and
Contact: Sibling Visitation and Ongoing Interaction
16

 DHHS Policy FOM 722-09 Updated Service Plan: Supervisory Approval
 DHHS Policy FOM 801 Medical Passports
 DHHS Policy FOM 801 Health Documentation: Dental Examination Schedule
The agency submitted a CAP on September 4, 2019 for the Interim Inspection that
was completed in July 2019. The CAP was approved on September 4, 2019. The
agency is in non-compliance with sections of the CAP, as the agency received the
following repeat violations during the current Renewal Inspection:
 R 400.12418 (2)(b) and (3) Development of service plans
 DHHS Policy FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings: Types and Timeframes
 DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H Caseworker Contact with Parent(s)/Guardian(s)
 DHHS Policy FOM 722-06I Maintaining Connections through Visitation and
Contact: Sibling Visitation and Ongoing Interaction
 DHHS Policy FOM 722-09 Updated Service Plan: Supervisory Approval
 DHHS Policy FOM 801 Medical Passports
 DHHS Policy FOM 801 Health Documentation: Dental Examination Schedule
SIR#2019C0221020 was initiated on April 15, 2019. ISEP 6.18 Relative Foster
Parent Licensing, Timeliness placement was cited as a result of this investigation.
The relative caregiver was not licensed within 180 days of the foster child’s
placement in her home. The agency submitted a CAP on May 20, 2019 and the CAP
was approved on May 23, 2019. The agency is in compliance with this CAP as they
did not receive a citation for ISEP 6.18 during the current Renewal Inspection.
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
17

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
